And here are their names: Shammua son of Zaccur from Reuben, Shaphat son of Hori from Simeon, Caleb son of Jephunneh from Judah, Igal son of Joseph from Issachar, Joshua son of Nun from Ephraim, Palti son of Raphu from Benjamin, Gaddiel son of Sodi from Zebulun, Gaddi son of Susi from Manasseh, Ammiel son of Gemalli from Dan, Sethur son of Michael from Asher, Nahbi son of Vophsi from Naphtali, and Geuel son of Machi from Gad.

17.verse: Before Moses sent them into Canaan, he said: After you go through the Southern Desert of Canaan, continue north into the hill country

18.verse: and find out what those regions are like. Be sure to remember how many people live there, how strong they are,

19.verse: and if they live in open towns or walled cities. See if the land is good for growing crops and find out what kinds of trees grow there. It’s time for grapes to ripen, so try to bring back some of the fruit that grows there.

20.verse: and if they live in open towns or walled cities. See if the land is good for growing crops and find out what kinds of trees grow there. It’s time for grapes to ripen, so try to bring back some of the fruit that grows there.

21.verse: The twelve men left to explore Canaan from the Zin Desert in the south all the way to the town of Rehob near Lebo-Hamath in the north.

22.verse: As they went through the Southern Desert, they came to the town of Hebron, which was seven years older than the Egyptian town of Zoan. In Hebron, they saw the three Anakim clans of Ahiman, Sheshai, and Talmai.

23.verse: When they got to Bunch Valley, they cut off a branch with such a huge bunch of grapes, that it took two men to carry it on a pole. That’s why the place was called Bunch Valley. Along with the grapes, they also took back pomegranates and figs.

24.verse: When they got to Bunch Valley, they cut off a branch with such a huge bunch of grapes, that it took two men to carry it on a pole. That’s why the place was called Bunch Valley. Along with the grapes, they also took back pomegranates and figs.

25.verse: The Men Report Back to the People - After exploring the land of Canaan forty days,

26.verse: the twelve men returned to Kadesh in the Paran Desert and told Moses, Aaron, and the people what they had seen. They showed them the fruit

27.verse: and said: Look at this fruit! The land we explored is rich with milk and honey.

28.verse: But the people who live there are strong, and their cities are large and walled. We even saw the three Anakim clans.

29.verse: Besides that, the Amalekites live in the Southern Desert; the Hittites, Jebusites, and Amorites are in the hill country; and the Canaanites live along the Mediterranean Sea and the Jordan River.

30.verse: Caleb calmed down the crowd and said, “Let’s go and take the land. I know we can do it!”

31.verse: But the other men replied, “Those people are much too strong for us.”

32.verse: Then they started spreading rumors and saying, “We won’t be able to grow anything in that soil. And the people are like giants.

33.verse: In fact, we saw the Nephilim who are the ancestors of the Anakim. They were so big that we felt as small as grasshoppers.”

1.verse: The Israelites Rebel against Moses - After the Israelites heard the report from the twelve men who had explored Canaan, the people cried all night

2.verse: and complained to Moses and Aaron, “We wish we had died in Egypt or somewhere out here in the desert!

3.verse: Is the LORD leading us into Canaan, just to have us killed and our women and children captured? We’d be better off in Egypt.”

4.verse: Then they said to one another, “Let’s choose our own leader and go back.”

5.verse: Moses and Aaron bowed down to pray in front of the crowd.

6.verse: Joshua and Caleb tore their clothes in sorrow

7.verse: and said: We saw the land ourselves, and it’s very good.

8.verse: If we obey the LORD, he will surely give us that land rich with milk and honey.

9.verse: So don’t rebel. We have no reason to be afraid of the people who live there. The LORD is on our side, and they won’t stand a chance against us!

10.verse: The crowd threatened to stone Moses and Aaron to death. But just then, the LORD appeared in a cloud at the sacred tent.

11.verse: Moses Prays for the People - The LORD said to Moses, “I have done great things for these people, and they still reject me by refusing to believe in my power.

12.verse: So they will no longer be my people. I will destroy them, but I will make you the ancestor of a nation even stronger than theirs.”

13.verse: Moses replied: With your mighty power you rescued your people from Egypt, so please don’t destroy us here in the desert. If you do, the Egyptians will hear about it and tell the people of Canaan. Those Canaanites already know that we are your people, and that we see you face to face. And they have heard how you lead us with a thick cloud during the day and flaming fire at night. But if you kill us, they will claim it was because you weren’t powerful enough to lead us into Canaan as you promised.

14.verse: Moses replied: With your mighty power you rescued your people from Egypt, so please don’t destroy us here in the desert. If you do, the Egyptians will hear about it and tell the people of Canaan. Those Canaanites already know that we are your people, and that we see you face to face. And they have heard how you lead us with a thick cloud during the day and flaming fire at night. But if you kill us, they will claim it was because you weren’t powerful enough to lead us into Canaan as you promised.

15.verse: Moses replied: With your mighty power you rescued your people from Egypt, so please don’t destroy us here in the desert. If you do, the Egyptians will hear about it and tell the people of Canaan. Those Canaanites already know that we are your people, and that we see you face to face. And they have heard how you lead us with a thick cloud during the day and flaming fire at night. But if you kill us, they will claim it was because you weren’t powerful enough to lead us into Canaan as you promised.

16.verse: Moses replied: With your mighty power you rescued your people from Egypt, so please don’t destroy us here in the desert. If you do, the Egyptians will hear about it and tell the people of Canaan. Those Canaanites already know that we are your people, and that we see you face to face. And they have heard how you lead us with a thick cloud during the day and flaming fire at night. But if you kill us, they will claim it was because you weren’t powerful enough to lead us into Canaan as you promised.

17.verse: Show us your great power, LORD. You promised

18.verse: that you love to show mercy and kindness. And you said that you are very patient, but that you will punish everyone guilty of doing wrong—not only them but their children and grandchildren as well.

19.verse: You are merciful, and you treat people better than they deserve. So please forgive these people, just as you have forgiven them ever since they left Egypt.

20.verse: Then the LORD said to Moses: In answer to your prayer, I do forgive them.

21.verse: But as surely as I live and my power has no limit,

22.verse: I swear that not one of these Israelites will enter the land I promised to give their ancestors. These people have seen my power in Egypt and in the desert, but they will never see Canaan. They have disobeyed and tested me too many times.

23.verse: I swear that not one of these Israelites will enter the land I promised to give their ancestors. These people have seen my power in Egypt and in the desert, but they will never see Canaan. They have disobeyed and tested me too many times.

24.verse: But my servant Caleb isn’t like the others. So because he has faith in me, I will allow him to cross into Canaan, and his descendants will settle there.

25.verse: Now listen, Moses! The Amalekites and the Canaanites live in the valleys of Canaan. And tomorrow morning, you’ll need to turn around and head back into the desert toward the Red Sea.

26.verse: The Israelites Are Punished for Complaining - The LORD told Moses and Aaron

27.verse: to give this message to the people of Israel: You sinful people have complained against me too many times! Now I swear by my own life that I will give you exactly what you wanted.

28.verse: to give this message to the people of Israel: You sinful people have complained against me too many times! Now I swear by my own life that I will give you exactly what you wanted.

29.verse: You will die right here in the desert, and your dead bodies will cover the ground. You have insulted me, and none of you men who are over twenty years old

30.verse: will enter the land that I solemnly promised to give you as your own—only Caleb and Joshua will go in.

31.verse: You were worried that your own children would be captured. But I, the LORD, will let them enter the land you have rejected.

32.verse: You will die here in the desert!

33.verse: Your children will wander around in this desert forty years, suffering because of your sins, until all of you are dead.

34.verse: I will cruelly punish you every day for the next forty years—one year for each day that the land was explored.

35.verse: You sinful people who ganged up against me will die here in the desert.

36.verse: Ten of the men sent to explore the land had brought back bad news and had made the people complain against the LORD.

37.verse: So he sent a deadly disease that killed those men,

38.verse: but he let Joshua and Caleb live.

39.verse: The Israelites Fail To Enter Canaan - The people of Israel were very sad after Moses gave them the LORD’s message.

40.verse: So they got up early the next morning and got ready to head toward the hill country of Canaan. They said, “We were wrong to complain about the LORD. Let’s go into the land that he promised us.”

41.verse: But Moses replied, “You’re disobeying the LORD! Your plan won’t work,

42.verse: so don’t even try it. The LORD refuses to help you, because you turned your backs on him. The Amalekites and the Canaanites are your enemies, and they will attack and defeat you.”

43.verse: so don’t even try it. The LORD refuses to help you, because you turned your backs on him. The Amalekites and the Canaanites are your enemies, and they will attack and defeat you.”

44.verse: But the Israelites ignored Moses and marched toward the hill country, even though the sacred chest and Moses did not go with them.

45.verse: The Amalekites and the Canaanites came down from the hill country, defeated the Israelites, and chased them as far as the town of Hormah.

1.verse: Laws about Sacrifices - The LORD told Moses

2.verse: to give the Israelites the following laws about offering sacrifices:

3.verse: Bulls or rams or goats are the animals that you may burn on the altar as sacrifices to please me. You may also offer sacrifices voluntarily or because you made a promise, or because they are part of your regular religious ceremonies. The smell of the smoke from these sacrifices is pleasing to me.

4.verse: If you sacrifice a young ram or goat, you must also offer two pounds of your finest flour mixed with a quart of olive oil as a grain sacrifice. A quart of wine must also be poured on the altar.

5.verse: If you sacrifice a young ram or goat, you must also offer two pounds of your finest flour mixed with a quart of olive oil as a grain sacrifice. A quart of wine must also be poured on the altar.

6.verse: And if the animal is a full-grown ram, you must offer four pounds of flour mixed with one and a half quarts of olive oil. One and a half quarts of wine must also be poured on the altar. The smell of this smoke is pleasing to me.

7.verse: And if the animal is a full-grown ram, you must offer four pounds of flour mixed with one and a half quarts of olive oil. One and a half quarts of wine must also be poured on the altar. The smell of this smoke is pleasing to me.

8.verse: If a bull is offered as a sacrifice to please me or to ask my blessing,

9.verse: you must offer six pounds of flour mixed with two quarts of olive oil.

10.verse: Two quarts of wine must also be poured on the altar. The smell of this smoke is pleasing to me.

11.verse: If you are a native Israelite, you must obey these rules each time you offer a bull, a ram, or a goat as a sacrifice.

12.verse: If you are a native Israelite, you must obey these rules each time you offer a bull, a ram, or a goat as a sacrifice.

13.verse: If you are a native Israelite, you must obey these rules each time you offer a bull, a ram, or a goat as a sacrifice.

14.verse: And the foreigners who live among you must also follow these rules.

15.verse: This law will never change. I am the LORD, and I consider all people the same, whether they are Israelites or foreigners living among you.

16.verse: This law will never change. I am the LORD, and I consider all people the same, whether they are Israelites or foreigners living among you.

17.verse: When you eat food in the land that I am giving you, remember to set aside some of it as an offering to me.

18.verse: When you eat food in the land that I am giving you, remember to set aside some of it as an offering to me.

19.verse: When you eat food in the land that I am giving you, remember to set aside some of it as an offering to me.

20.verse: From the first batch of bread dough that you make after each new grain harvest, make a loaf of bread and offer it to me, just as you offer grain.

21.verse: All your descendants must follow this law and offer part of the first batch of bread dough.

22.verse: The LORD also told Moses to tell the people what must be done if they ever disobey his laws:

23.verse: The LORD also told Moses to tell the people what must be done if they ever disobey his laws:

24.verse: If all of you disobey one of my laws without meaning to, you must offer a bull as a sacrifice to please me, together with a grain sacrifice, a wine offering, and a goat as a sacrifice for sin.

25.verse: Then the priest will pray and ask me to forgive you. And since you did not mean to do wrong, and you offered sacrifices,

26.verse: the sin of everyone—both Israelites and foreigners among you—will be forgiven.

27.verse: But if one of you does wrong without meaning to, you must sacrifice a year-old female goat as a sacrifice for sin.

28.verse: The priest will then ask me to forgive you, and your sin will be forgiven.

29.verse: The law will be the same for anyone who does wrong without meaning to, whether an Israelite or a foreigner living among you.

30.verse: But if one of you does wrong on purpose, whether Israelite or foreigner, you have sinned against me by disobeying my laws. You will be sent away and will no longer live among the people of Israel.

31.verse: But if one of you does wrong on purpose, whether Israelite or foreigner, you have sinned against me by disobeying my laws. You will be sent away and will no longer live among the people of Israel.

32.verse: A Man Put to Death for Gathering Firewood on the Sabbath - Once, while the Israelites were traveling through the desert, a man was caught gathering firewood on the Sabbath.

33.verse: He was taken to Moses, Aaron, and the rest of the community.

34.verse: But no one knew what to do with him, so he was not allowed to leave.

35.verse: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Tell the people to take that man outside the camp and stone him to death!”

36.verse: So he was killed, just as the LORD had commanded Moses.

37.verse: The Tassels on the People’s Clothes - The LORD told Moses

38.verse: to say to the people of Israel, “Sew tassels onto the bottom edge of your clothes and tie a purple string to each tassel.

39.verse: These will remind you that you must obey my laws and teachings. And when you do, you will be dedicated to me and won’t follow your own sinful desires.

40.verse: These will remind you that you must obey my laws and teachings. And when you do, you will be dedicated to me and won’t follow your own sinful desires.

41.verse: I am the LORD your God who led you out of Egypt.”

1.verse: Korah, Dathan, and Abiram Lead a Rebellion - Korah son of Izhar was a Levite from the Kohathite clan. One day he called together Dathan, Abiram, and On from the Reuben tribe, and the four of them decided to rebel against Moses. So they asked two hundred fifty respected Israelite leaders for their support, and together they went to Moses

2.verse: Korah, Dathan, and Abiram Lead a Rebellion - Korah son of Izhar was a Levite from the Kohathite clan. One day he called together Dathan, Abiram, and On from the Reuben tribe, and the four of them decided to rebel against Moses. So they asked two hundred fifty respected Israelite leaders for their support, and together they went to Moses

3.verse: and Aaron and said, “Why do you think you’re so much better than anyone else? We’re part of the LORD’s holy people, and he’s with all of us. What makes you think you’re the only ones in charge?”

4.verse: When Moses heard this, he knelt down to pray.

5.verse: Then he said to Korah and his followers: Tomorrow morning the LORD will show us the person he has chosen to be his priest, and that man will faithfully serve him.

6.verse: Korah, now here is what you and your followers must do: Get some fire pans, fill them with coals and incense, and place them near the sacred tent. And the man the LORD chooses will be his priest. Korah, this time you Levites have gone too far!

7.verse: Korah, now here is what you and your followers must do: Get some fire pans, fill them with coals and incense, and place them near the sacred tent. And the man the LORD chooses will be his priest. Korah, this time you Levites have gone too far!

8.verse: You know that the God of Israel has chosen you Levites from all Israel to serve him by being in charge of the sacred tent and by helping the community to worship in the proper way. What more do you want?

9.verse: You know that the God of Israel has chosen you Levites from all Israel to serve him by being in charge of the sacred tent and by helping the community to worship in the proper way. What more do you want?

10.verse: The LORD has given you a special responsibility, and now, Korah, you think you should also be his priest.

11.verse: You and your followers have rebelled against the LORD, not against Aaron.

12.verse: Then Moses sent for Dathan and Abiram, but they sent back this message: “We won’t come!

13.verse: It’s bad enough that you took us from our rich farmland in Egypt to let us die here in the desert. Now you also want to boss us around!

14.verse: You keep promising us rich farmlands with fertile fields and vineyards—but where are they? Stop trying to trick these people. No, we won’t come to see you.”

15.verse: Moses was very angry and said to the LORD, “Don’t listen to these men! I haven’t done anything wrong to them. I haven’t taken as much as a donkey.”

16.verse: Then he said to Korah, “Tomorrow you and your followers must go with Aaron to the LORD’s sacred tent.

17.verse: Each of you take along your fire pan with incense in it and offer the incense to the LORD.”

18.verse: The next day the men placed incense and coals in their fire pans and stood with Moses and Aaron at the entrance to the sacred tent.

19.verse: Meanwhile, Korah had convinced the rest of the Israelites to rebel against their two leaders. When that happened, the LORD appeared in all his glory

20.verse: and said to Moses and Aaron,

21.verse: “Get away from the rest of the Israelites so I can kill them right now!”

22.verse: But the two men bowed down and prayed, “Our God, you gave these people life. Why would you punish everyone here when only one man has sinned?”

23.verse: The LORD answered Moses,

24.verse: “Tell the people to stay away from the tents of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram.”

25.verse: Moses walked over to Dathan and Abiram, and the other leaders of Israel followed.

26.verse: Then Moses warned the people, “Get away from the tents of these sinful men! Don’t touch anything that belongs to them or you’ll be wiped out.”

27.verse: So everyone moved away from those tents, except Korah, Dathan, Abiram, and their families.

28.verse: Moses said to the crowd, “The LORD has chosen me and told me to do these things—it wasn’t my idea. And here’s how you will know:

29.verse: If these men die a natural death, it means the LORD hasn’t chosen me.

30.verse: But suppose the LORD does something that has never been done before. For example, what if a huge crack appears in the ground, and these men and their families fall into it and are buried alive, together with everything they own? Then you will know they have turned their backs on the LORD!”

31.verse: As soon as Moses said this, the ground under the men opened up

32.verse: and swallowed them alive, together with their families and everything they owned. Then the ground closed back up, and they were gone.

33.verse: and swallowed them alive, together with their families and everything they owned. Then the ground closed back up, and they were gone.

34.verse: The rest of the Israelites heard their screams, so they ran off, shouting, “We don’t want that to happen to us!”

35.verse: Suddenly the LORD sent a fire that burned up the two hundred fifty men who had offered incense to him.

36.verse: Then the LORD said to Moses,

37.verse: “Tell Aaron’s son Eleazar to take the fire pans from the smoldering fire and scatter the coals. The pans are now sacred,

38.verse: because they were used for offering incense to me. Have them hammered into a thin layer of bronze as a covering for the altar. Those men died because of their sin, and now their fire pans will become a warning for the rest of the community.”

39.verse: Eleazar collected the pans and had them hammered into a thin layer of bronze as a covering for the altar,

40.verse: just as the LORD had told Moses. The pans were a warning to the Israelites that only Aaron’s descendants would be allowed to offer incense to the LORD. Anyone else who tried would be punished like Korah and his followers.

41.verse: The Israelites Rebel and Are Punished - The next day the people of Israel again complained against Moses and Aaron, “The two of you killed some of the LORD’s people!”

42.verse: As the people crowded around them, Moses and Aaron turned toward the sacred tent, and the LORD appeared in his glory in the cloud covering the tent.

43.verse: So Moses and Aaron walked to the front of the tent,

44.verse: where the LORD said to them,

45.verse: “Stand back! I am going to wipe out these Israelites once and for all.” They immediately bowed down and prayed.

46.verse: Then Moses told Aaron, “Grab your fire pan and fill it with hot coals from the altar. Put incense in it, then quickly take it to where the people are and offer it to the LORD, so they can be forgiven. The LORD is very angry, and people have already started dying!”

47.verse: Aaron did exactly what he had been told. He ran over to the crowd of people and stood between the dead bodies and the people who were still alive. He placed the incense on the pan, then offered it to the LORD and asked him to forgive the people’s sin. The disease immediately stopped spreading, and no one else died from it.

48.verse: Aaron did exactly what he had been told. He ran over to the crowd of people and stood between the dead bodies and the people who were still alive. He placed the incense on the pan, then offered it to the LORD and asked him to forgive the people’s sin. The disease immediately stopped spreading, and no one else died from it.

49.verse: But fourteen thousand seven hundred Israelites were dead, not counting those who had died with Korah and his followers.

50.verse: Aaron walked back and stood with Moses at the sacred tent.

1.verse: Aaron’s Walking Stick Blooms and Produces Almonds - The LORD told Moses:

2.verse: Call together the twelve tribes of Israel and tell the leader of each tribe to write his name on the walking stick he carries as a symbol of his authority. Make sure Aaron’s name is written on the one from the Levi tribe, then collect all the sticks.

3.verse: Call together the twelve tribes of Israel and tell the leader of each tribe to write his name on the walking stick he carries as a symbol of his authority. Make sure Aaron’s name is written on the one from the Levi tribe, then collect all the sticks.

4.verse: Place these sticks in the tent right in front of the sacred chest where I appear to you.

5.verse: I will then choose a man to be my priest, and his stick will sprout. After that happens, I won’t have to listen to any more complaints about you.

6.verse: Moses told the people what the LORD had commanded, and they gave him the walking sticks from the twelve tribal leaders, including Aaron’s from the Levi tribe.

7.verse: Moses took them and placed them in the LORD’s sacred tent.

8.verse: The next day when Moses went into the tent, flowers and almonds were already growing on Aaron’s stick.

9.verse: Moses brought the twelve sticks out of the tent and showed them to the people. Each of the leaders found his own and took it.

10.verse: But the LORD told Moses, “Put Aaron’s stick back! Let it stay near the sacred chest as a warning to anyone who might think about rebelling. If these people don’t stop their grumbling about me, I will wipe them out.”

11.verse: Moses did what he was told.

12.verse: The Israelites cried out to Moses, “We’re done for

13.verse: and doomed if we even get near the sacred tent!”

1.verse: The Duties of the Priests and Levites - The LORD said to Aaron: You, your sons, and the other Levites of the Kohath clan, are responsible for what happens at the sacred tent. And you and your sons will be responsible for what the priests do.

2.verse: The Levites are your relatives and are here to help you in your service at the tent.

3.verse: You must see that they perform their duties. But if they go near any of the sacred objects or the altar, all of you will die.

4.verse: No one else is allowed to take care of the sacred tent or to do anything connected with it.

5.verse: Follow these instructions, so I won’t become angry and punish the Israelites ever again.

6.verse: I alone chose the Levites from all the other tribes to belong to me, and I have given them to you as your helpers.

7.verse: But only you and your sons can serve as priests at the altar and in the most holy place. Your work as priests is a gift from me, and anyone else who tries to do that work must be put to death.

8.verse: The Priests' Share of Offerings Given to the LORD - The LORD said to Aaron: I have put you in charge of the sacred gifts and sacrifices that the Israelites bring to me. And from now on, you, your sons, and your descendants will receive part of the sacrifices for sin, as well as part of the grain sacrifices, and the sacrifices to make things right. Your share of these sacrifices will be the parts not burned on the altar.

9.verse: The Priests' Share of Offerings Given to the LORD - The LORD said to Aaron: I have put you in charge of the sacred gifts and sacrifices that the Israelites bring to me. And from now on, you, your sons, and your descendants will receive part of the sacrifices for sin, as well as part of the grain sacrifices, and the sacrifices to make things right. Your share of these sacrifices will be the parts not burned on the altar.

10.verse: Since these things are sacred, they must be eaten near the sacred tent, but only men are allowed to eat them.

11.verse: You will also receive part of the special gifts and offerings that the Israelites bring to me. Any member of your family who is clean and acceptable for worship can eat these things.

12.verse: For example, when the Israelites bring me the first batches of oil, wine, and grain, you can have the best parts of those gifts.

13.verse: And the first part of the crops from their fields and vineyards also belongs to you. The people will offer this to me, then anyone in your family who is clean may have some of it.

14.verse: Everything in Israel that has been completely dedicated to me will now belong to you.

15.verse: The first-born son in every Israelite family, as well as the first-born males of their flocks and herds, belong to me. But a first-born son and every first-born donkey must be bought back from me.

16.verse: The price for a first-born son who is at least one month old will be five pieces of silver, weighed according to the official standards.

17.verse: However, all first-born cattle, sheep, and goats belong to me and cannot be bought back. Splatter their blood on the altar and send their fat up in smoke, so I can smell it and be pleased.

18.verse: You are allowed to eat the meat of those animals, just as you can eat the choice ribs and the right hind leg of the special sacrifices.

19.verse: From now on, the sacred offerings that the Israelites give to me will belong to you, your sons, and your daughters. This is my promise to you and your descendants, and it will never change.

20.verse: You will not receive any land in Israel as your own. I am the LORD, and I will give you whatever you need.

21.verse: What the Levites Receive - The LORD said to Aaron: Ten percent of the Israelites' crops and one out of every ten of their newborn animals belong to me. But I am giving all this to the Levites as their pay for the work they do at the sacred tent.

22.verse: They are the only ones allowed to work at the tent, and they must not let anyone else come near it. Those who do must be put to death, and the Levites will also be punished. This law will never change. Since the Levites won’t be given any land in Israel as their own,

23.verse: They are the only ones allowed to work at the tent, and they must not let anyone else come near it. Those who do must be put to death, and the Levites will also be punished. This law will never change. Since the Levites won’t be given any land in Israel as their own,

24.verse: they will be given the crops and newborn animals that the Israelites offer to me.

25.verse: What the Levites Must Give - The LORD told Moses

26.verse: to say to the Levites: When you receive from the people of Israel ten percent of their crops and newborn animals, you must offer a tenth of that to me.

27.verse: Just as the Israelites give me part of their grain and wine, you must set aside part of what you receive

28.verse: as an offering to me. That amount must then be given to Aaron,

29.verse: so the best of what you receive will be mine.

30.verse: After you have dedicated the best parts to me, you can eat the rest, just as the Israelites eat part of their grain and wine after offering them to me.

31.verse: Your share may be eaten anywhere by anyone in your family, because it is your pay for working at the sacred tent.

32.verse: You won’t be punished for eating it, as long as you have already offered the best parts to me. The gifts and sacrifices brought by the people must remain sacred, and if you eat any part of them before they are offered to me, you will be put to death.

1.verse: The Ceremony To Wash Away Sin - The LORD gave Moses and Aaron the following law: The people of Israel must bring Moses a reddish-brown cow that has nothing wrong with it and that has never been used for plowing.

2.verse: The Ceremony To Wash Away Sin - The LORD gave Moses and Aaron the following law: The people of Israel must bring Moses a reddish-brown cow that has nothing wrong with it and that has never been used for plowing.

3.verse: Moses will give it to Eleazar the priest, then it will be led outside the camp and killed while Eleazar watches.

4.verse: He will dip his finger into the blood and sprinkle it seven times in the direction of the sacred tent.

5.verse: Then the whole cow, including its skin, meat, blood, and insides must be burned.

6.verse: A priest is to throw a stick of cedar wood, a hyssop branch, and a piece of red yarn into the fire.

7.verse: After the ceremony, the priest is to take a bath and wash his clothes. Only then can he go back into the camp, but he remains unclean and unfit for worship until evening.

8.verse: The man who burned the cow must also wash his clothes and take a bath, but he is also unclean until evening.

9.verse: A man who isn’t unclean must collect the ashes of the burnt cow and store them outside the camp in a clean place. The people of Israel can mix these ashes with the water used in the ceremony to wash away sin.

10.verse: The man who collects the ashes must wash his clothes, but will remain unclean until evening. This law must always be obeyed by the people of Israel and the foreigners living among them.

11.verse: What Must Be Done after Touching a Dead Body - The LORD said: If you touch a dead body, you will be unclean for seven days.

12.verse: But if you wash with the water mixed with the cow’s ashes on the third day and again on the seventh day, you will be clean and acceptable for worship. You must wash yourself on those days; if you don’t, you will remain unclean.

13.verse: Suppose you touch a dead body, but refuse to be made clean by washing with the water mixed with ashes. You will be guilty of making my sacred tent unclean and will no longer belong to the people of Israel.

14.verse: If someone dies in a tent while you are there, you will be unclean for seven days. And anyone who later enters the tent will also be unclean.

15.verse: Any open jar in the tent is unclean.

16.verse: If you touch the body of someone who was killed or who died of old age, or if you touch a human bone or a grave, you will be unclean for seven days.

17.verse: Before you can be made clean, someone who is clean must take some of the ashes from the burnt cow and stir them into a pot of spring water. That same person must dip a hyssop branch in the water and ashes, then sprinkle it on the tent and everything in it, including everyone who was inside. If you have touched a human bone, a grave, or a dead body, you must be sprinkled with that water.

18.verse: Before you can be made clean, someone who is clean must take some of the ashes from the burnt cow and stir them into a pot of spring water. That same person must dip a hyssop branch in the water and ashes, then sprinkle it on the tent and everything in it, including everyone who was inside. If you have touched a human bone, a grave, or a dead body, you must be sprinkled with that water.

19.verse: If this is done on the third day and on the seventh day, you will be clean. Then after you take a bath and wash your clothes, you can worship that evening.

20.verse: If you are unclean and refuse to be made clean by washing with the water mixed with ashes, you will be guilty of making my sacred tent unclean, and you will no longer belong to the people of Israel.

21.verse: These laws will never change. The man who sprinkled the water and the ashes on you when you were unclean must also wash his clothes. And whoever touches this water is unclean until evening.

22.verse: When you are unclean, everything you touch becomes unclean, and anyone who touches you will be unclean until evening.

1.verse: Water from a Rock - The people of Israel arrived at the Zin Desert during the first month and set up camp near the town of Kadesh. It was there that Miriam died and was buried.

2.verse: The Israelites had no water, so they went to Moses and Aaron

3.verse: and complained, “Moses, we’d be better off if we had died along with the others in front of the LORD’s sacred tent.

4.verse: You brought us into this desert, and now we and our livestock are going to die!

5.verse: Egypt was better than this horrible place. At least there we had grain and figs and grapevines and pomegranates. But now we don’t even have any water.”

6.verse: Moses and Aaron went to the entrance to the sacred tent, where they bowed down. The LORD appeared to them in all of his glory

7.verse: and said, “Moses, get your walking stick. Then you and Aaron call the people together and command that rock to give you water. That’s how you will provide water for the people of Israel and their livestock.”

8.verse: and said, “Moses, get your walking stick. Then you and Aaron call the people together and command that rock to give you water. That’s how you will provide water for the people of Israel and their livestock.”

9.verse: Moses obeyed and took his stick from the sacred tent.

10.verse: After he and Aaron had gathered the people around the rock, he said, “Look, you rebellious people, and you will see water flow from this rock!”

11.verse: He raised his stick in the air and struck the rock two times. At once, water gushed from the rock, and the people and their livestock had water to drink.

12.verse: But the LORD said to Moses and Aaron, “Because you refused to believe in my power, these people did not respect me. And so, you will not be the ones to lead them into the land I have promised.”

13.verse: The Israelites had complained against the LORD, and he had shown them his holy power by giving them water to drink. So they named the place Meribah, which means “Complaining.”

14.verse: Israel Isn’t Allowed To Go through Edom - Moses sent messengers from Israel’s camp near Kadesh with this message for the king of Edom: We are Israelites, your own relatives, and we’re sure you have heard the terrible things that have happened to us.

15.verse: Our ancestors settled in Egypt and lived there a long time. But later the Egyptians were cruel to us,

16.verse: and when we begged our LORD for help, he answered our prayer and brought us out of that land. Now we are camped at the border of your territory, near the town of Kadesh.

17.verse: Please let us go through your country. We won’t go near your fields and vineyards, and we won’t drink any water from your wells. We will stay on the main road until we leave your territory.

18.verse: But the Edomite king answered, “No, I won’t let you go through our country! And if you try, we will attack you.”

19.verse: Moses sent back this message: “We promise to stay on the main road, and if any of us or our livestock drink your water, we will pay for it. We just want to pass through.”

20.verse: But the Edomite king insisted, “You can’t go through our land!” Then Edom sent out its strongest troops

21.verse: to keep Israel from passing through its territory. So the Israelites had to go in another direction.

22.verse: Aaron Dies - After the Israelites had left Kadesh and had gone as far as Mount Hor

23.verse: on the Edomite border, the LORD said,

24.verse: “Aaron, this is where you will die. You and Moses disobeyed me at Meribah, and so you will not enter the land I promised the Israelites.

25.verse: Moses, go with Aaron and his son Eleazar to the top of the mountain.

26.verse: Then take Aaron’s priestly robe from him and place it on Eleazar. Aaron will die there.”

27.verse: Moses obeyed, and everyone watched as he and Aaron and Eleazar walked to the top of Mount Hor.

28.verse: Moses then took the priestly robe from Aaron and placed it on Eleazar. Aaron died there. When Moses and Eleazar came down,

29.verse: the people knew that Aaron had died, and they mourned his death for thirty days.

1.verse: Israel Defeats the Canaanites at Hormah - The Canaanite king of Arad lived in the Southern Desert of Canaan, and when he heard that the Israelites were on their way to the village of Atharim, he attacked and took some of them hostage.

2.verse: The Israelites prayed, “Our LORD, if you will help us defeat these Canaanites, we will completely destroy their towns and everything in them, to show that they belong to you.”

3.verse: The LORD answered their prayer and helped them wipe out the Canaanite army and completely destroy their towns. That’s why one of the towns is named Hormah, which means “Destroyed Place.”

4.verse: Moses Makes a Bronze Snake - The Israelites had to go around the territory of Edom, so when they left Mount Hor, they headed south toward the Red Sea. But along the way, the people became so impatient

5.verse: that they complained against God and said to Moses, “Did you bring us out of Egypt, just to let us die in the desert? There’s no water out here, and we can’t stand this awful food!”

6.verse: Then the LORD sent poisonous snakes that bit and killed many of them.

7.verse: Some of the people went to Moses and admitted, “It was wrong of us to insult you and the LORD. Now please ask him to make these snakes go away.” Moses prayed,

8.verse: and the LORD answered, “Make a snake out of bronze and place it on top of a pole. Anyone who gets bitten can look at the snake and won’t die.”

9.verse: Moses obeyed the LORD. And all of those who looked at the bronze snake lived, even though they had been bitten by the poisonous snakes.

10.verse: Israel’s Journey to Moab - As the Israelites continued their journey to Canaan, they camped at Oboth,

11.verse: then at Iye-Abarim in the desert east of Moab,

12.verse: and then in the Zered Gorge.

13.verse: After that, they crossed the Arnon River gorge and camped in the Moabite desert bordering Amorite territory. The Arnon was the border between the Moabites and the Amorites.

14.verse: A song in The Book of the LORD’s Battles mentions the town of Waheb with its creeks in the territory of Suphah. It also mentions the Arnon River,

15.verse: with its valleys that lie alongside the Moabite border and extend to the town of Ar.

16.verse: From the Arnon, the Israelites went to the well near the town of Beer, where the LORD had said to Moses, “Call the people together, and I will give them water to drink.”

17.verse: That’s also the same well the Israelites sang about in this song: Let’s celebrate! The well has given us water.

18.verse: With their royal scepters, our leaders pointed out where to dig the well. The Israelites left the desert and camped near the town of Mattanah,

19.verse: then at Nahaliel, and then at Bamoth.

20.verse: Finally, they reached Moabite territory, where they camped near Mount Pisgah in a valley overlooking the desert north of the Dead Sea.

21.verse: Israel Defeats King Sihon the Amorite - The Israelites sent this message to King Sihon of the Amorites:

22.verse: Please let us pass through your territory. We promise to stay away from your fields and vineyards, and we won’t drink any water from your wells. As long as we’re in your land, we won’t get off the main road.

23.verse: But Sihon refused to let Israel travel through his land. Instead, he called together his entire army and marched into the desert to attack Israel near the town of Jahaz.

24.verse: Israel defeated them and took over the Amorite territory from the Arnon River gorge in the south to the Jabbok River gorge in the north. Beyond the Jabbok was the territory of the Ammonites, who were much stronger than Israel.

25.verse: The Israelites settled in the Amorite towns, including the capital city of Heshbon with its surrounding villages.

26.verse: King Sihon had ruled from Heshbon, after defeating the Moabites and taking over their land north of the Arnon River gorge.

27.verse: That’s why the Amorites had written this poem about Heshbon: Come and rebuild Heshbon, King Sihon’s capital city!

28.verse: His armies marched out like fiery flames, burning down the town of Ar and destroying the hills along the Arnon River.

29.verse: You Moabites are done for! Your god Chemosh deserted your people; they were captured, taken away by King Sihon the Amorite.

30.verse: We completely defeated Moab. The towns of Heshbon and Dibon, of Nophah and Medeba are ruined and gone.

31.verse: After the Israelites had settled in the Amorite territory,

32.verse: Moses sent some men to explore the town of Jazer. Later, the Israelites captured the villages surrounding it and forced out the Amorites who lived there.

33.verse: Israel Defeats King Og of Bashan - The Israelites headed toward the region of Bashan, where King Og ruled, and he led his entire army to Edrei to meet Israel in battle.

34.verse: The LORD said to Moses, “Don’t be afraid of Og. I will help you defeat him and his army, just as you did King Sihon who ruled in Heshbon. Og’s territory will be yours.”

35.verse: So the Israelites wiped out Og, his family, and his entire army—there were no survivors. Then Israel took over the land of Bashan.

1.verse: Israel moved from there to the hills of Moab, where they camped across the Jordan River from the town of Jericho.

2.verse: King Balak of Moab Hires Balaam To Curse Israel - When King Balak of Moab and his people heard how many Israelites there were and what they had done to the Amorites, he and the Moabites were terrified and panicked.

3.verse: King Balak of Moab Hires Balaam To Curse Israel - When King Balak of Moab and his people heard how many Israelites there were and what they had done to the Amorites, he and the Moabites were terrified and panicked.

4.verse: They said to the Midianite leaders, “That bunch of Israelites will wipe out everything in sight, like a bull eating grass in a field.” So King Balak

5.verse: sent a message to Balaam son of Beor who lived among his relatives in the town of Pethor near the Euphrates River. It said: I need your help. A huge group of people has come here from Egypt and settled near my territory.

6.verse: They are too powerful for us to defeat, so would you come and place a curse on them? Maybe then we can run them off. I know that anyone you bless will be successful, but anyone you curse will fail.

7.verse: The leaders of Moab and Midian left and took along money to pay Balaam for his work. When they got to his house, they gave him Balak’s message.

8.verse: “Spend the night here,” Balaam replied, “and tomorrow I will tell you the LORD’s answer.” So the officials stayed at his house.

9.verse: During the night, God asked Balaam, “Who are these people at your house?”

10.verse: “They are messengers from King Balak of Moab,” Balaam answered. “He sent them

11.verse: to ask me to go to Moab and place a curse on the people who have come there from Egypt. They have settled everywhere around him, and he wants to run them off.”

12.verse: But God replied, “Don’t go with Balak’s messengers. I have blessed those people who have come from Egypt, so don’t curse them.”

13.verse: The next morning, Balaam said to Balak’s officials, “Go on back home. The LORD says I cannot go with you.”

14.verse: The officials left and told Balak that Balaam refused to come.

15.verse: Then Balak sent a larger group of officials, who were even more important than the first ones.

16.verse: They went to Balaam and told him that Balak had said, “Balaam, if you come to Moab,

17.verse: I’ll pay you very well and do whatever you ask. Just come and place a curse on these people.”

18.verse: Balaam answered, “Even if Balak offered me a palace full of silver or gold, I wouldn’t do anything to disobey the LORD my God.

19.verse: You are welcome to spend the night here, just as the others did. I will find out if the LORD has something else to say about this.”

20.verse: That night, God said, “Balaam, I’ll let you go to Moab with Balak’s messengers, but do only what I say.”

21.verse: So Balaam got up the next morning and saddled his donkey, then left with the Moabite officials.

22.verse: Balaam and His Donkey Meet an Angel - Balaam was riding his donkey to Moab, and two of his servants were with him. But God was angry that Balaam had gone, so one of the LORD’s angels stood in the road to stop him.

23.verse: When Balaam’s donkey saw the angel standing there with a sword, it walked off the road and into an open field. Balaam had to beat the donkey to get it back on the road.

24.verse: Then the angel stood between two vineyards, in a narrow path with a stone wall on each side.

25.verse: When the donkey saw the angel, it walked so close to one of the walls that Balaam’s foot scraped against the wall. Balaam beat the donkey again.

26.verse: The angel moved once more and stood in a spot so narrow that there was no room for the donkey to go around.

27.verse: So it just lay down. Balaam lost his temper, then picked up a stick and smacked the donkey.

28.verse: When that happened, the LORD told the donkey to speak, and it asked Balaam, “What have I done to you that made you beat me three times?”

29.verse: “You made me look stupid!” Balaam answered. “If I had a sword, I’d kill you here and now!”

30.verse: “But you’re my owner,” replied the donkey, “and you’ve ridden me many times. Have I ever done anything like this before?” “No,” Balaam admitted.

31.verse: Just then, the LORD let Balaam see the angel standing in the road, holding a sword, and Balaam bowed down.

32.verse: The angel said, “You had no right to treat your donkey like that! I was the one who blocked your way, because I don’t think you should go to Moab.

33.verse: If your donkey had not seen me and stopped those three times, I would have killed you and let the donkey live.”

34.verse: Balaam replied, “I was wrong. I didn’t know you were trying to stop me. If you don’t think I should go, I’ll return home right now.”

35.verse: “It’s all right for you to go,” the LORD’s angel answered. “But you must say only what I tell you.” So Balaam went on with Balak’s officials.

36.verse: King Balak Meets Balaam - When Balak heard that Balaam was coming, he went to meet him at the town of Ir, which is on the northern border of Moab.

37.verse: Balak asked, “Why didn’t you come when I invited you the first time? Did you think I wasn’t going to pay you?”

38.verse: “I’m here now,” Balaam answered. “But I will say only what God tells me to say.”

39.verse: They left and went to the town of Kiriath-Huzoth,

40.verse: where Balak sacrificed cattle and sheep and gave some of the meat to Balaam and the officials who were with him.

41.verse: The next morning, Balak took Balaam to the town of Bamoth-Baal. From there, Balaam could see some of the Israelites.

1.verse: Balaam’s First Message - Balaam said to Balak, “Build seven altars here, then bring seven bulls and seven rams.”

2.verse: After Balak had done this, they sacrificed a bull and a ram on each altar.

3.verse: Then Balaam said, “Wait here beside your offerings, and I’ll go somewhere to be alone. Maybe the LORD will appear to me. If he does, I will tell you everything he says.” And he left.

4.verse: When God appeared to him, Balaam said, “I have built seven altars and have sacrificed a bull and a ram on each one.”

5.verse: The LORD gave Balaam a message, then sent him back to tell Balak.

6.verse: When Balaam returned, he found Balak and his officials standing beside the offerings.

7.verse: Balaam said: “King Balak of Moab brought me from the hills of Syria to curse Israel and announce its doom.

8.verse: But I can’t go against God! He did not curse or condemn Israel.

9.verse: “From the mountain peaks, I look down and see Israel, the obedient people of God.

10.verse: They are living alone in peace. And though they are many, they don’t bother the other nations. “I hope to obey God for as long as I live and to die in such peace.”

11.verse: Balak said, “What are you doing? I asked you to come and place a curse on my enemies. But you have blessed them instead!”

12.verse: Balaam answered, “I can say only what the LORD tells me.”

13.verse: Balaam’s Second Message - Balak said to Balaam, “Let’s go somewhere else. Maybe if you see a smaller part of the Israelites, you will be able to curse them for me.”

14.verse: So he took Balaam to a field on top of Mount Pisgah where lookouts were stationed. Then he built seven altars there and sacrificed a bull and a ram on each one.

15.verse: “Wait here beside your offerings,” Balaam said. “The LORD will appear to me over there.”

16.verse: The LORD appeared to Balaam and gave him another message, then he told him to go and tell Balak.

17.verse: Balaam went back and saw him and his officials standing beside the offerings. Balak asked, “What did the LORD say?”

18.verse: Balaam answered: “Pay close attention to my words—

19.verse: God is no mere human! He doesn’t tell lies or change his mind. God always keeps his promises.

20.verse: “My command from God was to bless these people, and there’s nothing I can do to change what he has done.

21.verse: Israel’s king is the LORD God. He lives there with them and intends them no harm.

22.verse: With the strength of a wild ox, God led Israel out of Egypt.

23.verse: No magic charms can work against them— just look what God has done for his people.

24.verse: They are like angry lions ready to attack; and they won’t rest until their victim is gobbled down.”

25.verse: Balak shouted, “If you’re not going to curse Israel, then at least don’t bless them.”

26.verse: “I’ve already told you,” Balaam answered. “I will say only what the LORD tells me.”

27.verse: Balaam’s Third Message - Balak said to Balaam, “Come on, let’s try another place. Maybe God will let you curse Israel from there.”

28.verse: So he took Balaam to Mount Peor overlooking the desert north of the Dead Sea.

29.verse: Balaam said, “Build seven altars here, then bring me seven bulls and seven rams.”

30.verse: After Balak had done what Balaam asked, he sacrificed a bull and a ram on each altar.

1.verse: Balaam was sure that the LORD would tell him to bless Israel again. So he did not use any magic to find out what the LORD wanted him to do, as he had the first two times. Instead, he looked out toward the desert

2.verse: and saw the tribes of Israel camped below. Just then, God’s Spirit took control of him,

3.verse: and Balaam said: “I am the son of Beor, and my words are true, so listen to my message!

4.verse: It comes from the LORD, the God All-Powerful. I bowed down to him and saw a vision of Israel.

5.verse: “People of Israel, your camp is lovely.

6.verse: It’s like a grove of palm trees or a garden beside a river. You are like tall aloe trees that the LORD has planted, or like cedars growing near water.

7.verse: You and your descendants will prosper like an orchard beside a stream. Your king will rule with power and be a greater king than Agag the Amalekite.

8.verse: With the strength of a wild ox, God led you out of Egypt. You will defeat your enemies, shooting them with arrows and crushing their bones.

9.verse: Like a lion you lie down, resting after an attack. Who would dare disturb you? “Anyone who blesses you will be blessed; anyone who curses you will be cursed.”

10.verse: When Balak heard this, he was so furious that he pounded his fist against his hand and said, “I called you here to place a curse on my enemies, and you’ve blessed them three times.

11.verse: Leave now and go home! I told you I would pay you well, but since the LORD didn’t let you do what I asked, you won’t be paid.”

12.verse: Balaam answered, “I told your messengers

13.verse: that even if you offered me a palace full of silver or gold, I would still obey the LORD. And I explained that I would say only what he told me.

14.verse: So I’m going back home, but I’m leaving you with a warning about what the Israelites will someday do to your nation.”

15.verse: Balaam’s Fourth Message - Balaam said: “I am the son of Beor, and my words are true, so listen to my message!

16.verse: My knowledge comes from God Most High, the LORD All-Powerful. I bowed down to him and saw a vision of Israel.

17.verse: “What I saw in my vision hasn’t happened yet. But someday, a king of Israel will appear like a star. He will wipe out you Moabites and destroy those tribes who live in the desert.

18.verse: Israel will conquer Edom and capture the land of that enemy nation.

19.verse: The king of Israel will rule and destroy the survivors of every town there.

20.verse: “And I saw this vision about the Amalekites: Their nation is now great, but it will someday disappear forever.

21.verse: “And this is what I saw about the Kenites: They think they’re safe, living among the rocks,

22.verse: but they will be wiped out when Assyria conquers them.

23.verse: “No one can survive if God plans destruction.

24.verse: Ships will come from Cyprus, bringing people who will invade the lands of Assyria and Eber. But finally, Cyprus itself will be ruined.”

25.verse: After Balaam finished, he started home, and Balak also left.

1.verse: The Israelites Worship Baal - While the Israelites were camped at Acacia, some of the men had sex with Moabite women.

2.verse: These women then invited the men to ceremonies where sacrifices were offered to their gods. The men ate the meat from the sacrifices and worshiped the Moabite gods.

3.verse: The LORD was angry with Israel because they had worshiped the god Baal Peor.

4.verse: So he said to Moses, “Take the Israelite leaders who are responsible for this and have them killed in front of my sacred tent where everyone can see. Maybe then I will stop being angry with the Israelites.”

5.verse: Moses told Israel’s officials, “Each of you must put to death any of your men who worshiped Baal.”

6.verse: Later, Moses and the people were at the sacred tent, crying, when one of the Israelite men brought a Midianite woman to meet his family.

7.verse: Phinehas, the grandson of Aaron the priest, saw the couple and left the crowd. He found a spear

8.verse: and followed the man into his tent, where he ran the spear through the man and into the woman’s stomach. The LORD immediately stopped punishing Israel with a deadly disease,

9.verse: but twenty-four thousand Israelites had already died.

10.verse: The LORD said to Moses,

11.verse: “In my anger, I would have wiped out the Israelites if Phinehas had not been faithful to me.

12.verse: But instead of punishing them, I forgave them. So because of the loyalty that Phinehas showed, I solemnly promise that he and his descendants will always be my priests.”

13.verse: But instead of punishing them, I forgave them. So because of the loyalty that Phinehas showed, I solemnly promise that he and his descendants will always be my priests.”

14.verse: The Israelite man that was killed was Zimri son of Salu, who was one of the leaders of the Simeon tribe.

15.verse: And the Midianite woman killed with him was Cozbi, the daughter of a Midianite clan leader named Zur.

16.verse: The LORD told Moses,

17.verse: “The Midianites are now enemies of Israel, so attack and defeat them! They tricked the people of Israel into worshiping their god at Peor, and they are responsible for the death of Cozbi, the daughter of one of their own leaders.”

18.verse: “The Midianites are now enemies of Israel, so attack and defeat them! They tricked the people of Israel into worshiping their god at Peor, and they are responsible for the death of Cozbi, the daughter of one of their own leaders.”

1.verse: The Israelites Are Counted a Second Time - After the LORD had stopped the deadly disease from killing the Israelites, he said to Moses and Eleazar son of Aaron,

2.verse: “I want you to find out how many Israelites are in each family. And list every man twenty years and older who is able to serve in Israel’s army.”

3.verse: Israel was now camped in the hills of Moab across the Jordan River from the town of Jericho. Moses and Eleazar told them

4.verse: what the LORD had said about counting the men twenty years and older, just as Moses and their ancestors had done when they left Egypt.

5.verse: There were 43,730 men from the tribe of Reuben, the oldest son of Jacob. These men were from the clans of Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.

6.verse: There were 43,730 men from the tribe of Reuben, the oldest son of Jacob. These men were from the clans of Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.

7.verse: There were 43,730 men from the tribe of Reuben, the oldest son of Jacob. These men were from the clans of Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.

8.verse: Pallu was the father of Eliab

9.verse: and the grandfather of Nemuel, Dathan, and Abiram. These are the same Dathan and Abiram who had been chosen by the people, but who followed Korah and rebelled against Moses, Aaron, and the LORD.

10.verse: That’s when the LORD made the earth open up and swallow Dathan, Abiram, and Korah. At the same time, fire destroyed two hundred fifty men as a warning to the other Israelites.

11.verse: But the Korahite clan wasn’t destroyed.

12.verse: There were 22,200 men from the tribe of Simeon; they were from the clans of Nemuel, Jamin, Jachin, Zerah, and Shaul.

Zelophehad son of Hepher had no sons, but he had five daughters: Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.

48.verse: There were 45,400 men from the tribe of Naphtali; they were from the clans of Jahzeel, Guni, Jezer, and Shillem.

51.verse: The total number of Israelite men listed was 601,730.

53.verse: “Divide the land of Canaan among these tribes, according to the number of people in each one,

54.verse: so the larger tribes have more land than the smaller ones.

55.verse: I will show you what land to give each tribe, and they will receive as much land as they need, according to the number of people in it.”

56.verse: I will show you what land to give each tribe, and they will receive as much land as they need, according to the number of people in it.”

57.verse: The tribe of Levi included the clans of the Gershonites, Kohathites, Merarites,

58.verse: as well as the clans of Libni, Hebron, Mahli, Mushi, and Korah. Kohath the Levite was the father of Amram,

59.verse: the husband of Levi’s daughter Jochebed, who was born in Egypt. Amram and Jochebed’s three children were Aaron, Moses, and Miriam.

60.verse: Aaron was the father of Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.

61.verse: But Nadab and Abihu had died when they offered fire that was unacceptable to the LORD.

62.verse: In the tribe of Levi there were 23,000 men and boys at least a month old. They were not listed with the other tribes, because they would not receive any land in Canaan.

63.verse: Moses and Eleazar counted the Israelites while they were camped in the hills of Moab across the Jordan River from Jericho.

64.verse: None of the people that Moses and Aaron had counted in the Sinai Desert were still alive,

65.verse: except Caleb son of Jephunneh and Joshua son of Nun. The LORD had said that everyone else would die there in the desert.

1.verse: The Daughters of Zelophehad Are Given Land - Zelophehad was from the Manasseh tribe, and he had five daughters, whose names were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.

2.verse: One day his daughters went to the sacred tent, where they met with Moses, Eleazar, and some other leaders of Israel, as well as a large crowd of Israelites. The young women said:

3.verse: You know that our father died in the desert. But it was for something he did wrong, not for joining with Korah in rebelling against the LORD. Our father left no sons

4.verse: to carry on his family name. But why should his name die out for that reason? Give us some land like the rest of his relatives in our clan, so our father’s name can live on.

5.verse: Moses asked the LORD what should be done,

6.verse: and the LORD answered:

7.verse: Zelophehad’s daughters are right. They should each be given part of the land their father would have received.

8.verse: Tell the Israelites that when a man dies without a son, his daughter will inherit his land.

9.verse: If he has no daughter, his brothers will inherit the land.

10.verse: But if he has no brothers, his father’s brothers will inherit the land.

11.verse: And if his father has no brothers, the land must be given to his nearest relative in the clan. This is my law, and the Israelites must obey it.

12.verse: Joshua Is Appointed Israel’s Leader - The LORD said to Moses, “One day you will go up into the Abarim Mountains, and from there you will see the land I am giving the Israelites.

13.verse: After you have seen it, you will die, just like your brother Aaron,

14.verse: because both of you disobeyed me at Meribah near the town of Kadesh in the Zin Desert. When the Israelites insulted me there, you didn’t believe in my holy power.”

15.verse: Moses replied,

16.verse: “You are the LORD God, and you know what is in everyone’s heart. So I ask you to appoint a leader for Israel.

17.verse: Your people need someone to lead them into battle, or else they will be like sheep wandering around without a shepherd.”

18.verse: The LORD answered, “Joshua son of Nun can do the job. Place your hands on him to show that he is the one to take your place.

19.verse: Then go with him and have him stand in front of Eleazar the priest and the Israelites. Appoint Joshua as their new leader

20.verse: and tell them they must now obey him, just as they obey you.

21.verse: But Joshua must depend on Eleazar to find out from me what I want him to do as he leads Israel into battle.”

22.verse: Moses followed the LORD’s instructions and took Joshua to Eleazar and the people,

23.verse: then he placed his hands on Joshua and appointed him Israel’s leader.

1.verse: Regular Daily Sacrifices - The LORD told Moses

2.verse: to say to the people of Israel: Offer sacrifices to me at the appointed times of worship, so that I will smell the smoke and be pleased.

3.verse: Each day offer two rams a year old as sacrifices to please me. The animals must have nothing wrong with them;

4.verse: one will be sacrificed in the morning, and the other in the evening.

5.verse: Along with each of them, two pounds of your finest flour mixed with a quart of olive oil must be offered as a grain sacrifice.

6.verse: This sacrifice to please me was first offered on Mount Sinai.

7.verse: Finally, along with each of these two sacrifices, a quart of wine must be poured on the altar as a drink offering.

8.verse: The second ram will be sacrificed that evening, along with the other offerings, just like the one sacrificed that morning. The smell of the smoke from these sacrifices will please me.

9.verse: The Sacrifice on the Sabbath - The LORD said: On the Sabbath, in addition to the regular daily sacrifices, you must sacrifice two rams a year old to please me. These rams must have nothing wrong with them, and they will be sacrificed with a drink offering and four pounds of your finest flour mixed with olive oil.

10.verse: The Sacrifice on the Sabbath - The LORD said: On the Sabbath, in addition to the regular daily sacrifices, you must sacrifice two rams a year old to please me. These rams must have nothing wrong with them, and they will be sacrificed with a drink offering and four pounds of your finest flour mixed with olive oil.

11.verse: The Sacrifices on the First Day of the Month - The LORD said: On the first day of each month, bring to the altar two bulls, one full-grown ram, and seven rams a year old that have nothing wrong with them. Then offer these as sacrifices to please me.

12.verse: Six pounds of your finest flour mixed with olive oil must be offered with each bull as a grain sacrifice. Four pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with the ram,

13.verse: and two pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with each of the young rams. The smell of the smoke from these sacrifices will please me.

14.verse: Offer two quarts of wine as a drink offering with each bull, one and a half quarts with the ram, and one quart with each of the young rams. Finally, you must offer a goat as a sacrifice for sin. These sacrifices are to be offered on the first day of each month, in addition to the regular daily sacrifices.

15.verse: Offer two quarts of wine as a drink offering with each bull, one and a half quarts with the ram, and one quart with each of the young rams. Finally, you must offer a goat as a sacrifice for sin. These sacrifices are to be offered on the first day of each month, in addition to the regular daily sacrifices.

16.verse: The Sacrifices during Passover and the Festival of Thin Bread - The LORD said: Celebrate Passover in honor of me on the fourteenth day of the first month of each year.

17.verse: The following day will begin the Festival of Thin Bread, which will last for a week. During this time you must honor me by eating bread made without yeast.

18.verse: On the first day of this festival, you must rest from your work and come together for worship.

19.verse: Bring to the altar two bulls, one full-grown ram, and seven rams a year old that have nothing wrong with them. And then offer these as sacrifices to please me.

20.verse: Six pounds of your finest flour mixed with olive oil must be offered with each bull as a grain sacrifice. Four pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with the ram,

21.verse: and two pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with each of the young rams.

22.verse: Also offer a goat as a sacrifice for the sins of the people.

23.verse: All of these are to be offered in addition to the regular daily sacrifices, and the smoke from them will please me.

24.verse: All of these are to be offered in addition to the regular daily sacrifices, and the smoke from them will please me.

25.verse: Then on the last day of the festival, you must once again rest from work and come together for worship.

26.verse: The Sacrifices during the Harvest Festival - The LORD said: On the first day of the Harvest Festival, you must rest from your work, come together for worship, and bring a sacrifice of new grain.

27.verse: Offer two young bulls, one full-grown ram, and seven rams a year old as sacrifices to please me.

28.verse: Six pounds of your finest flour mixed with olive oil must be offered with each bull as a grain sacrifice. Four pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with the ram,

29.verse: and two pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with each of the young rams.

30.verse: Also offer a goat as a sacrifice for sin.

31.verse: The animals must have nothing wrong with them and are to be sacrificed along with the regular daily sacrifices.

1.verse: The Sacrifices at the Festival of Trumpets - The LORD said: On the first day of the seventh month, you must rest from your work and come together to celebrate at the sound of the trumpets.

2.verse: Bring to the altar one bull, one full-grown ram, and seven rams a year old that have nothing wrong with them. And then offer these as sacrifices to please me.

3.verse: Six pounds of your finest flour mixed with olive oil must be offered with the bull as a grain sacrifice. Four pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with the ram,

4.verse: and two pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with each of the young rams.

5.verse: You must also offer a goat as a sacrifice for sin.

6.verse: These sacrifices will be made in addition to the regular daily sacrifices and the sacrifices for the first day of the month. The smoke from these sacrifices will please me.

7.verse: The Sacrifices on the Great Day of Forgiveness - The LORD said: The tenth day of the seventh month is the Great Day of Forgiveness. On that day you must rest from all work and come together for worship. Show sorrow for your sins by going without food,

8.verse: and bring to the altar one young bull, one full-grown ram, and seven rams a year old that have nothing wrong with them. Then offer these as sacrifices to please me.

9.verse: Six pounds of your finest flour mixed with olive oil must be offered with the bull as a grain sacrifice. Four pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with the ram,

10.verse: and two pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with each of the young rams.

11.verse: A goat must also be sacrificed for the sins of the people. You will offer these sacrifices in addition to the sacrifice to ask forgiveness and the regular daily sacrifices.

12.verse: The Sacrifices during the Festival of Shelters - The LORD said: Beginning on the fifteenth day of the seventh month and continuing for seven days, everyone must celebrate the Festival of Shelters in honor of me.

13.verse: On the first day, you must rest from your work and come together for worship. Bring to the altar thirteen bulls, two full-grown rams, and fourteen rams a year old that have nothing wrong with them. Then offer these as sacrifices to please me.

14.verse: Six pounds of your finest flour mixed with olive oil must be offered with each bull as a grain sacrifice. Four pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with each of the rams,

15.verse: and two pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with each of the young rams.

16.verse: You must also offer a goat as a sacrifice for sin. These are to be offered in addition to the regular daily sacrifices.

17.verse: For the next six days of the festival, you will sacrifice one less bull than the day before, so that on the seventh day, seven bulls will be sacrificed. The other sacrifices and offerings must remain the same for each of these days.

18.verse: For the next six days of the festival, you will sacrifice one less bull than the day before, so that on the seventh day, seven bulls will be sacrificed. The other sacrifices and offerings must remain the same for each of these days.
